boardgame.name: Geharrewar in de Sushi-bar
Sushi Bar
Sushizock
Sushizock im Gockelwok
美味刺壽司
boardgame.description:
This is another game in Zoch's "small square box" line and seems to be a follow-up to Reiner Knizia's Pickomino.

There are five dice. Each dice has:

2 x Sushi (blue)
2 x Fishbone (red)
1 x Chopsticks (blue)
1 x Chopsticks (red)

There are 24 tiles:

12 x Sushi (blue) ... Worth +1 to +6 points
12 x Fishbone (red) ... Worth -1 to -4 points

Players roll dice to try and collect "Sushi" and "Fish Bone" tiles from the centre of the board (the tile they get depends how many they rolled).

Players can also steal tiles from other players by rolling 3 or more appropriately coloured "Chopsticks" on their dice. 3 Chopsticks allows you to take the top tile from an appropriate pile from another player, 4 or 5 chopsticks allows you to nominate which tile from the pile you want, but you are not allowed to look first.

At the end of the game (when the tiles are all gone), players score points based on the tiles they have collected, however if you have more blue tiles than red tiles, you lose the excess blue tiles first!

This game is part of The Chicken Family of Zoch.

boardgame.name: Power Checkers
boardgame.description:
Power Checkers is an expansion of the traditional game of Checkers. Game play is similar to the original game with the same movement, jumping, and kinging rules. The major difference comes in the expanded board, which allows for more maneuverability and the ability for special "Power" moves.

Players start with their pieces in special territories outside of the regular 8x8 board. To get Power Checker status, the player must get his or her piece all the way through the opponent's home territory to special Power spaces. Once there, the piece may move in any direction, transport to special Power Space Courts outside of the normal play area, and return to their home area.

The game is playable with 2-4 single players or team play.

boardgame.name: Serpentine
boardgame.description:
Serpentine ... a 2, 3, or 4-player abstract strategy family board game.

The board consists of streamers with missing intersections and played with 84 tokens, in 4 colours, that are 2-sided with a straight streamer on one side and a curved streamer on the reverse.
In turn, players place their colour tokens on these spaces.

The goal is to form the longest possible same-colour Serpentine streamer.

The game has 3 levels of play:
Level 1 – in turn, players place one of their tokens on an empty space - and the turn is over. When the board is full or there are no more tokens to be placed, in order to form the longest possible streamer, on their next turn, players rotate or invert one of their own tokens in place.

Level 2 – players place one of their tokens on an empty space. During the same turn, a player may either:
1) Rotate or invert an opponent’s token without breaking a continuous streamer.
2) Move one of their own colour tokens to an empty space, thereby possibly breaking their own streamer.

Level 2 – players take these actions in the following order:
1) Place one of their tokens on an empty space.
2) Move any one of the opponent’s tokens to an adjacent empty space without rotating or inverting it.
3) Move any one of their tokens to an empty space on the board without rotating or inverting it ~ or, rotate or invert one of their own tokens in place.

The player with the longest continuous Serpentine streamer is the winner.

boardgame.name: Makin' Movies
boardgame.description:
MAKIN' MOVIES is a card game about collecting the right actors and money to make a movie.

You are a low budget movie producer and your goal is to compete against other players to be the first to collect enough money and the right actors to make your movie. Use your money to protect your actors from other players, or hire their actors! It's a simple card game with many options and different ways to win.
Each turn every player has 3 actions which represent; Holding auditions, casting for roles in your movie and hiring actors from other players.

The game concludes with the winning player naming their movie or giving a quick advertisement trailer for their movie based on the strange collection of actors they have hired.

The FREE Print and Play game contains 44 actor cards, 12 money cards, 8 scripts.

Retail Version contains 50 actors, 12 money cards, and 10 scripts.

boardgame.name: Superman
boardgame.description:
Roll-and-Move game where each player controls a superman pawn.

Object of the Game: Be the first player to bring your Villain to Jail and disarm his Secret Weapon at the Crime Lab.

Each player moves around the board uncovering question mark tokens in the hopes of finding the appropriate villain. Once found, they put the villain into the holder on their pawn and take him to jail.

After depositing the villains in jail, each player must find and disarm their secret weapon. The first player to disarm their secret weapon (by spinning an even number while the weapon is in their possession) wins.

boardgame.name: Dig & Play Treasure Island
boardgame.description:
Gameplay is composed of two phases.

Initially, the game parts must be physically dug out of a block of plaster. This takes the theme (digging for buried treasure) and puts players to the act of literally digging their way through to actual treasure. This is a one-time-event only, although it may take a few hours to fully accomplish.

Next, once the parts have been recovered, players use pieces to move around a pirate's treasure map. This is a basically simple map, and may only hold the attention of children if they have actually dug the pieces out themselves, and may then appreciate the effort involved.

The game contains
24 tiles of each color (blue and red)
2 wooden pawns
2 wooden towers (score markers)
1 board

The players place alternately their tiles face down on the board and start at the score of 50 points. The aim of the game is to grab all tiles of your opponent. Each player also has 4 additional tiles with a treasure chest, lady, dragon, and a ghost - worth respectively 20, 10, 10, or 10 points, when getting your opponents' tiles, or losing the same amount when drawing your own tiles.

boardgame.name: Tetrade
boardgame.description: Tetrade is a three dimensional boardgame on a triangular board with six holes on each side. Players put spheres in alternate turns and try to occupy the four corners of a tetrahedron with the size of 2,3,4,5 or 6 elements. Three spheres of lower level carry one sphere of higher level. A player succeeding in forming a tetrahedron receives a sphere from the hand of the opponent, so that this player is stalemated at the end of the game.

"The Finland game is a boardgame for 2-4 players, where every player can learn about the possibilities of Finland as a holiday destination by doing a tour of Finland."

Depending on the desired game length players get a number of cards corresponding with destinations on the board which have to be reached by moving the player's pawn across the board. There are also additional cards which the players can get by standing on yellow spaces on the board which give players additional destinations to visit or the possibility to e.g. use air travel to move faster. The game ends as soon as a player has no destination cards left in his hand.

Het Finlandspel is a promotional game distributed by travel agencies in the Netherlands in the early 1990s.

boardgame.name: Het Groot Van Dale Spel der Nederlandse Taal
boardgame.description:
(from back of the box, translated from Dutch)
"Test your knowledge of our language! A box full of spelling questions and a box full of word knowledge questions. Thousands of difficulties. As player you always choose the level on which you want to play. And...every player can win! Collect three dictionaries and "click" them onto your pawn! Play on safe (green), play with some guts (blue), or are your ready to face a red question? Who challenges whom? Never was "educational" this much fun! So exciting! And of course: the name Van Dale guarantees high quality"

Het groot van Dale spel der Nederlandse taal is a word game based on the major dictionary of the Dutch language. It consists of a board over which the players move their pawns, answering questions pertaining to the Dutch language, in the fields of word knowledge and spelling. Correct answers earn dictionary markers which are put under the pawn. Depending on whether a player has one, two or three dictionaries, the questions become increasingly difficult, making the end game a challenge. The game ends when a player reaches the finish space on the board while having three dictionary markers.

This game is the same as Das grosse Dudenspiel and Oxford: the Great Oxford Game of the English Language, but in Dutch.

boardgame.name: Sinyavino 1942
Sinyavino 1942! The Leningrad Relief Offensive
boardgame.description:
From the designer's website:

Sinyavino Offensive covers the "crossfire" offensive conducted by the Soviet forces in August, 1942. Crossfire, for it was a daring offensive from two opposite directions focused on a single objective: to free the isolated forces and people of Leningrad before the Germans conducted their own operation to seize the city! The bottleneck area held by German forces was no more than a few miles wide and defended by no more than three divisions. From the East, the Soviets would toss a total of 14 divisions and 100 tanks to smash the Nazi. From the West, across the Neva River, another 2-3 divisions and a tank brigade would conduct an amphibious assault. The battle would last over 30 days and desperate for both sides. At first, Red forces seriously broke through, forcing Hitler to cancel his own offensive to seize Leningrad and divert General Mainstein's forces to save the impending disaster. The battle was also the debut for Germany's new AFV, the Tiger tank!

Contains:
• 11" x 17" map
• 280 counters
• 11 page rules
• 2 page Player aid

boardgame.name: Warcosm
boardgame.description:
WARCOSM is an easy-to-learn and quick-paced tabletop game that simulates fleet-based space battles using either miniatures or flat counters.

Maneuver the enemy so that you can bring more weapons to bear on them. Find an enemy craft’s weaknesses to maximize the effectiveness of your attacks. Warcosm’s game mechanics encourage such tactics without overwhelming you with endless rules. This permits each player to control six, ten, or even a few dozen ships for scalable battles. Once you get the hang of the rules with the included battle scenarios, use the ship construction rules to build your own fleets. Decide how to arm your ships, the degree and types of hull protection, the power of drive systems, and whether or not to equip them with a number of other subsystems. The fate of the galaxy is in your hands. Command your fleets and lead them to Victory in the Stars.

Available in PDF format, and as a Printed Starter Set with hex-grid sheets, cardboard counters, ready-to-use fleet rosters, and 10-sided die.

boardgame.name: Pala
boardgame.description:
In the trick-taking card game Pala, players are art students who are learning to mix their pigments on the palette to get the right color for their canvases. The cards are the paint colors, and the palette is the table. By playing cards together (that is, mixing colors), you can effectively change the color of your cards as well as the trick itself.

The published version of Pala includes two ways to play. Both variants use the same mechanisms for playing tricks, but have different bidding and score rules. Thus, once you wrap your head around the basics of the game, you can play two wildly different games with those core rules.


In Impressionism, players collectively determine the value of different colors (suits) by discarding cards from their hands before the round begins. Points are bad, analogous to Hearts.



In Pointillism, players bid with colored chips to indicate the colors they expect to win, but over-bidding risks losing all your points for the round. Points are good, analogous to Spades.

boardgame.name: The Big Time!
boardgame.description:
In The Big Time!, players take the role of theater owners in Chicago during the Golden Age of vaudeville from about 1905 to about 1915. The object is to make your theater the most spectacular in the city by booking the greatest and most diverse roster of acts that you can find (and afford!).

You win the game by having the highest score on the Success Track, which represents public approbation and goodwill. While money is an important part of running a successful theater, there've gotta be easier ways to make a living than dealing with a never-ending procession of ventriloquists, jugglers, and trained animals! No, you're in this business because greasepaint is in your blood, and you can't imagine a world without limelight.

In each of four turns, players bid on the right to select acts first and place those acts in their theaters. After your theaters are booked, you tally up scores to see who was the most successful. Good shows will drive up the reputation of your theater and influence the popularity of the types of acts that you book, but a flop can always set you back!

Soldiers: at least 60 army men preferably in two colors
Tanks: at least 6 die cast metal cars (hot-wheels, matchbox, etc)

boardgame.name: Kraków 1325 AD
boardgame.description:
Krakow 1325 AD is a 4-player card game full of trickery, which interacts with a map board. The game was first presented to the boardgaming world at Spiel 08 in Essen (October 2008) in two versions - English and Dutch.

The setting is Krakow, capital of Medieval Poland. The players form into two teams of ruthless crooks, which compete for influence and riches through a card game using a deck of 56 special "Intrigue Cards". But below the surface, things get uglier: every player has a hidden Identity and secretly competes against all others, including his own teammate. And there can be only one winner at game end...

The game comprises a mapboard, a card set of 56 Intrigue and 8 Special Cards, 4 Treasury boxes, 110 wooden Influence Tokens and 10 Victory Point/Turn markers.

Krakow 1325 AD is a game of strategy and trickery, overloaded with original artwork and a warped sense of humour.

In October 2009, a 3-player expansion to Krakow 1325 AD was published (English/Dutch and German versions).

The game can be ordered directly from the designer/publisher by sending a private mail through Boardgamegeek.

Shatranj Kamil
Tamerlane Chess
boardgame.description:
Tamerlane Chess is a strategic board game related to chess and shatranj. It was developed in Persia and was favored by the 14th century Turco-Mongol conqueror Timur the Lame (also known as "Tamerlane"), who thought regular (queen's) chess was not complex enough.

boardgame.name: Hullunkuriset lauseet
Phrases De Fous
Silly Sentences
Skųre sętninger
Skųre_sętninger
Zotte Zinnen
boardgame.description:
Players complete sentences by placing jigsaw pieces with words on them from their hand.

The shape of the 124 puzzle pieces enforces correct grammar in the sentence, but the sentences can be very silly indeed such as "The furry clock ate the big princess." or "A blue crocodile jumped over the school."

All the pieces except the 40 nouns are dealt to players. The nouns are reserved in a stock for players to select one when they want/need to. A players hand goes down by one, except when they play a noun.

The winner is the one to get rid of all their words first. The strategy is therefore to block other players and force them to select nouns because they cannot play any other valid words.

Along the way a lot of fun is had by placing unexpected nouns in the sentences. Subtitled "grammar skills practice for the first three years of school", various classroom activities are also possible and included in the note to parents and teachers that accompanies the rules.

Staxx is part of Ashburn Industries' "The Quickles" series of card games.

Staxx uses a modified standard deck of cards, with two letters on each card and 6 wilds (effectively the jokers and kings). Staxx combines a standard Rummy game with a word game; players score the most for runs and sets that form words, but can meld just words or sets/runs.

boardgame.name: Osaki ni Shitsurei Shima-su!!
お先に失礼しま～す!!
boardgame.description:
It's quitting time at the office and everyone wants to go home. Unfortunately, there are still many jobs to finish tonight. It's a race to get out of the office first!

Players are dealt a face-down hand of six tiles corresponding to the six people in the office. On a player's turn they can either (1) turn over one of their tiles -- revealing which of the four jobs that person has been tasked with; or (2) place a tile or stack of tiles on top of another tile or stack of tiles that share a common characteristic (either person or job). Play continues until the last face-down tile is turned over. Whoever has the fewest tiles in front of them (i.e., the least overtime work to do) wins!

boardgame.name: Trick & Treat!
トリック＆トリート！
boardgame.description:
It's time for some Halloween mischief. The parents pick the tricks and everyone tries to accumulate the treats. Who will be able to get the most candy?

The deck contains 90 number cards in 6 suits and 16 trick cards. The number cards are dealt out to the players. Players take turns choosing the "tricks" -- rules for different types of card tricks. Rules include the One-Shot (everyone plays a card simultaneously and the highest card gets points), the Center (everyone plays a card simultaneously and everything except the high and low cards gets points), and the Single Color (players play cards once around following suit if possible with the highest card in the led suit getting points). Play continues until all cards have been played. Whoever accumulates the most points wins!

boardgame.name: Pyramid Pyramid

boardgame.description:
The Pharaoh is getting old and he does not have a successor. One day he gathers his closest advisers and issues a challenge: "Build me a pyramid. Whoever contributes the most shall be the next Pharaoh!". Who will rise the challenge and become the new ruler of the land?

Players roll dice and draw event cards to maneuver their pyramid-building blocks around the board and into the pyramid at the center. Points are scored for each block added to the pyramid. Bonus points are given for blocks that end up on the outside of the pyramid. Players need to manage their supply of building blocks carefully since the board is cleared after each level of the pyramid is completed and buying back the blocks costs points. After the pyramid is completed whoever has the most points wins.

boardgame.name: DEFCON ONE: The Cold War Goes Hot
boardgame.description:
The year is 1959 and world has descended into madness. A Capitalist Empire, lead from Washington D.C., is locked in mortal conflict with the Communist Bloc, controlled by an iron fisted Kremlin. For how eagerly the two sides have rattled their sabers, neither power is truly prepared for total war in the nuclear age. Tanks and missile cruisers, jet fighters and Kalashnikovs, roll off assembly lines and straight into one of a dozen charred wastelands strewn across the globe. Each side prays for a quick victory, as neither can sustain the horrors of the nuclear age for long.

DEFCON 1 is a diceless wargame meant to loosely simulate a nuclear war between the US and the Soviet Union. The game supposes that neither nation’s economy is prepared for nuclear conflict. Production represents the sole random chance element in the game. Each turn, players draw random units according to the size of their economy, and strategically deploy them across the globe, each side struggling to achieve victory by taking their opponent’s homeland before their economy suffers total collapse.

boardgame.name: Balloon Race
boardgame.description:
Can you get all your balloons safely into the stratosphere? But watch out for falling hailstones!

Each player has 4 balloons and tries to move all of them from the bottom to the top row of the Sky Grid. The first player to do so wins the game. If a balloon hits a hailstone then the balloon is burst and returns to the bottom row. Players may also burst other players balloons by squashing it between their own balloons and/or a hailstone. Balloons can jump diagonally over balloons of the same colour (counts as one move) all the way up the Sky Grid thus being an efficient way of using the action-points allocated each turn.

To begin a game, the 10 hailstones are lined up in the stratosphere (one in each square). Each player places their pawn on the corresponding 'Big Balloon' space on the Flight Path on the outside of the board. Then players place their balloons on any squares on the bottom of the Sky Grid (each player places one balloon in turn until all balloons are placed). Several balloons can occupy the same square for the first 3 rows (green area). Beyond row 3 (in the blue area) - only one balloon to a square.

On a player's turn they roll a 10-sided dice and move their pawn around the Flight Path. When the pawn lands on or passes certain squares it gives that player a number of action-points (1-4) in which to move their balloons in an upwards direction (vertical or diagonal). The action-points may be split among the player's balloons as they see fit. When a player's pawn lands on a 'Storm Clouds' square on the Flight Path the player must move any hailstone of their choice down one square. If a player's pawn lands on a 'Wind Clouds' square the player must move any one of their balloons one square sideways (if that is impossible - their lowest balloon is deemed burst, and falls back to the ground.)

Players can choose to stop their pawn on the Storm/Wind Clouds squares even if the number thrown on the dice could take the pawn past.

When a player's pawn passes or lands on a Kite/Cloud square in the corner of the Flight Path the player also throws the dice to determine which of the 10 hailstones moves down one square.

The game ends when one player has moved all their balloons to the top of the Sky Grid or when a hailstone hits the ground (in which case each balloon carries a score for the height it has reached, the highest total score then wins the game). For a quicker game, players can agree that the first balloon to reach the stratosphere ends the game - then the highest total score wins.

boardgame.name: Lumps, the Elf Coal Game
Lumps, the Game of Big Rolls and Smart Holds
Lumps: The Coal Dice Game
boardgame.description:
The goal is to be the first player to score 100 points. On each turn, a player gets three rolls to make as many points as possible. After the first roll the player must hold at least four dice. At the end of the second rolle the player must have at least six dice held. You score points by rolling the same number on your dice. If you roll a pair of 2s, you get two points. If you roll a pair of 6s, you get six points. For each additional die with the same number you score that number again. So, for three 6s you score twelve, six for the pair of 6s and six for the additional 6. Four 6s would score 18 and so on. There are also bonuses for all evens or odds, six or more dice of the same number or in sequence.

What makes the game unique is that it uses four different types of dice, each with a different highest number. For example, the game has two 10 sided dice and their highest number is 10. They are the only dice that can make a pair of ten. All dice have the numbers 1-4 on them, so it is much easier to get lower numbers.

Each turn players have to use strategy to determine which dice they’ve rolled are the best to keep and the best to re-roll. Do you chance it and try to roll another 8, or play it safe and hold a pair of 4s? Figuring out the right move in a game with countless possibilities will keep you thinking, laughing and cheering for hours on end.

Description from the publisher:

Modern Land Battles (MLB): Target Acquired uses the core game mechanisms from our award-winning Modern Naval Battles game. MLB takes you to the front lines in both historical and hypothetical conflicts ranging from the Arab-Israeli Wars to the present day.

This new game features armor, infantry and artillery vehicles from 7 different nations: USA, USSR, UK, China, Israel, Insurgent, and Arabian Multinational. This gives you the forces you need to play out battles during the Cold War, Six-Day War, Iran-Iraq War, Vietnam War, Lebanon War, Yom Kippur War, Falkland Islands War, and Gulf War.

The game system maximizes player decision making to make every turn exciting. At the start of the game, you get to select a nation's ground forces to command. Then, you get to select the specific armor, infantry, and artillery forces that you think is the best battle force. Once selected, you'll get to battle the forces selected by the other players in order to capture and secure vital objectives!

boardgame.name: Co-op Train Game
boardgame.description:
A cooperative print-and-play children's game where one to four players work together to try to complete as many deliveries as possible before nightfall.

The board depicts 16 stations connected by rail lines. On the delivery stations (beige), one of each of the eight destination tiles are placed randomly, face up. On each of the pick-up stations (green), two passenger/freight tiles are placed randomly, face down. Players roll a die to move (and sometimes advance the sun along its path in the sky). As trains arrive at a pick-up station, players reveal the goods/passengers. Sometimes, the player will load them onto their cars (limited number of cars on each train). Sometimes, they will leave them for other players to pick up. A player can even take a passenger part-way and leave them for another train to complete the job later.

The idea is to work together to see how many jobs will be completed before the game ends.

boardgame.name: Flinke Bürste

The title translates to Quick (tooth) Brush.

Two horseshoe shaped wood pieces carry 20 wooden teeth pieces, zero to three wood rings are laid over the teeth, the players walk around this "mouth" with their pieces, wooden tooth brushes. One die shows how far they may go, another die specifies what action to perform: brush away one ring, two rings, do nothing or advance a bacterium to the teeth.
If the bacterium reaches the teeth before the players have cleaned all of them, the players lose.

boardgame.name: Black Market
Schwarzmarkt
boardgame.description:
From the website of the publisher:

Black Market is like Kogge a trading game without money. The game is played in rounds, each round the players produce goods which they try to exchange for goods produced by the other players. Only goods which have been exchanged this way can then be sold for victory points. The exchange value of goods depends from supply and demand and will change from round to round.

The game Black market has won the 3rd price at the Hippodice game designer contest 2003 as Merkantilismus. There are some small changes to this version.

Black Market will be published during the Essen convention 2008 as a small (110 copies) handmade game.

boardgame.name: Get Castro!
boardgame.description:
The players represent various elements of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) seeking to assassinate Fidel Castro back in the fifties and sixties.

The game uses a custom deck of 57 cards. There are seven types of cards: Method, Conspiracy, Location, Save, Event, Propaganda, and Spy.

The players attempt to play melds of cards of the same type. Once you have three melds in play (one each for Method, Conspiracy, and Location), you may make an Assassination Attempt die roll to see if you kill Castro. If the roll is not successful, you lose some or all of your melds and the game continues.

Save and Event cards can be used to require an opponent to discard a meld. Propaganda cards allow a player to draw additional cards. Spy cards allow you to look at an opponent's cards and steal one.

"Winning: Be the first player to Assassinate Castro. If Castro is not killed after the players have gone through the deck twice then Castro survives and all the players lose."

"The experiment in particular is a machine he designed to breed a better rat (because the kids these days had gone and invented a better mousetrap). It is a mixture of mechanical and electronic feeder/torturing device."

"The object of the player (called Igor) is to have his favourite rat the biggest by the time the master returns."

"This involves making sure that toggles tilt the pipes in the machine such that the food pellets go to the player's rat - and avoiding/rotating the shocking motor such that the other rats are shocked (which causes them to lose food pellets, probably through vomiting)."

boardgame.name: Warp Dungeons
boardgame.description:
"This is a modifiable dungeon-crawling game for 2-4 players."

One player takes on the role of the Dungeon Master. The other players each control a Hero who is exploring the dungeon. The game uses three to five custom card decks: a DM Deck (60 cards), a Dungeon Deck (30 cards), and a Hero Deck for each Hero player (60 cards.)

The Dungeon Deck consists of cards specifying rooms and passages which are used to randomly create the dungeon. A Hero Deck consists of cards for various actions and treasures. The DM Deck consists primarily of cards representing monsters and traps.

The Hero players win if the Objective room card is located and resolved. The DM player wins if all of the Heroes are killed before they resolve the Objective room.

boardgame.name: Temples & Swords
boardgame.description:
"This game simulates the growth of ancient empires. Each player leads a young empire and controls its growth through its development. The units used to represent people are populations and monetary units are measured in gold points."

"Use a piece of hex paper and color equal numbers of squares green for grassland and yellow for desert. Each player chooses a starting grassland hex and puts a city and 3 population points on that hex. No two starting hexes may be closer than three hexes from each other."

The players build their empires by constructing cities, roads, temples, walls, marketplaces, and libraries. There are also three types of military forces available to attack opposing empires: Soldiers, Swordsmen, and Horsemen. The game also covers concepts such as disasters, technological advances, taxes, and population migration.

"Victory occurs when, at the end of his turn, a player has 20 victory points or has destroyed or captured all enemy cities, armies and populations." Victory Points are scored for cities, temples, and technological advances.

boardgame.name: Solo Crusade
boardgame.description:
"Solo Crusade is a simple set of rules to play a solo adventure with your favourite RPG. The underlying idea is very simple: one or more pools of 'tiles' are used to represent the map, the encounters, the events and in general every possible obstacle/help during your quest."

"Using a pool of tiles rather than simply roll some dices to create the adventure has a some major of advantages"

"• Visual representation of your travel: the tiles played on the table are much more " satisfactory" than a never-ending sequence of dice rolls."

"• Better control of the random factor: you can have tiles that can be drawn only once, tiles that are replaced when played."

This set of rules allows you to play out solo RPG adventures on the tabletop, similar to games such as DeathMaze and the Metagaming MicroQuests series. The rules include tables and instructions for four sample adventures: The Wilderness, Hobgoblin Forest, Hunt for the Tribe, and the Black Pit.

boardgame.description:
"Card & Record Keeping Game for 2-4+ players. Each player is a European Imperial Power circa 1500-1750."

The players seek to conquer 40 territories spread across five regions: the Caribbean, South America, Central America, North America, and Canada. Rather than relying on a map board, each territory is represented by a card in the Exploration Deck.

Players can gain control of territories through colonization or military conquest. The capability to do so depends on successful production and trade efforts, which provide the resources required to raise armies, build ships, and hire workers. The players must also be ready to cope with random events, such as piracy, storms, and revolutions.

boardgame.description:
Description extrapolated from TheBigGameHunter.com:

ZULU BLOW GUN GAME (1925, Zulu Game Co., Battle Creek, Michigan) comes from a category of games no longer available: the "projectile" game. Safety requirements have virtually eliminated all sharp, pointed projectiles from games (other than DARTS), and although the packaging on the ZULU BLOW GUN GAME states "harmless," the game's bamboo dart, when made airborne from the blowgun, could pierce many things, including body parts. Object was to score points by hitting different valued targets using the blowgun and bamboo darts.

boardgame.name: Warp Empires
boardgame.description:
"Generic rule set for a series of empire building/conquest games."

Games designed to be played using the Warp Empires system are called Warp Empires modules. Each module describes the units and other components needed to play the module.

Warp Empires modules are generally played on a map composed of irregular areas or territories. Counters are used to represent units, items, and control markers.

Card play is central to the system. One or more Action Decks are used in each module. Action Cards are played to move units or stacks. In addition, some Action Cards provide benefits in combat.

Victory conditions generally involve controlling a certain number of territories or destroying all opposing forces, as specified in the individual Warp Empires module.

The following games use the Warp Empires system:


Babylon 5 Empires
Conquest of Demara
Dark Sun Empires
Doctor Who Empires
Doom Trooper Empires

boardgame.name: Cadbury's Milk Tray Man In Black Game
boardgame.description:
From the box cover:

"Cadbury's Milk Tray MAN IN BLACK Game - an exciting and sophisticated game of skill, nerve and strategy for 2-4 players.

Players become the mysterious 'Man In Black' and:
- encounter landslides, avalanches and floods!
- block your opponents and deliver the box of Milk Tray
- make incredible get-aways by car or helicopter"

The game was produced by Waddington's games in the UK as a promotional item for Cadbury's "Milk Tray" chocolates. The advertising campaign for Milk Tray featured arguably the most famous advertising character in British TV history, the Milk Tray Man, a pseudo James Bond character who performed several death defying feats in order to deliver a box of chocolates.

Game contents:
- 1 plastic playing area, in two parts
- 76 hexagonal route tiles
- 4 "Men In Black" playing pieces
- 4 helicopters
- 4 getaway cars
- 6 getaway route tiles (double sided)
- 4 landslide markers
- 4 tree markers
- 1 "Man In Black" trump tile
- 1 "Lady" tile
- 1 "Start" tile
- dice and shaker

The object of the game is for each player to race their individual "Man In Black" piece from the Start hexagon tile, across the playing area, and to the Lady hexagon tile.

Each player is dealt 5 route tiles, a "Man In Black" playing piece, a getaway car piece and a helicopter piece.

On their turn, each player has the choice of either placing a Route tile on the board, or throwing a dice to see how many squares they can move their piece along already placed Route tiles.

Each route tile features a different road segment marked with squares. Some squares feature hazards which delay the player. Route tiles can be placed in any position, at any time throughout the game, on each players turn.

The getaway car, helicopter, landslide and tree markers can be used to move the players piece further, or to obstruct other players.

Game components consist of quality heavy duty card tiles, a moulded plastic board, and hand painted pieces.

The game is notable for being one of the earliest examples of a tile laying game, with each game producing a new road layout for players to travel.

Pyramid Power Game
boardgame.description:
The goal of Pyramid Power is to play all of your Pyramid tiles and to score points. A pyramid tile is a triangular tile with each corner of the triangle being one color.

When a Pyramid tile is played, the corner colors must match the corner colors of tiles already played. Players score the value of the tile played. If the Pyramid tile matches on the more than one side, bonuses are scored.

If a player has unplayable tiles, the player draws one tile to try and play. The first player to play all of their Pyramid tiles ends the game and scores as a bonus the value of the other players remaining Pyramid tiles. High score is the winner.

boardgame.name: Alfred's Wyke
boardgame.description:
Published in Games Magazine in September 2008, Alfred's Wyke is a two player game where one plays the Builder, the other the Destroyer. Square tiles are place in 2×2 plots that are arranged on a 4×4 grid (except for one pair of opposite corners that start with just 3 tiles). The Builder tries to build up two-story "houses" (2×2×2), while the Destroyer tries completely demolish buildings in order to create empty plots (2×2×0). On each turn, the players select from a menu of five tile placement/removal options:

1-1-1-1-1 (one at each of five different plots) Note: If and only if each player has claimed six plots, meaning only four plots remain unclaimed, this option becomes 1-1-1-1.
2-1-1 (two at one plot; one at each of two others)
2-2 (two at each of two plots)
3-1 (three at one plot; one at another)
4 (four at one plot)


However, after each player has taken one turn, only three are available on any turn, because a player cannot pick a set that has been selected in the previous two turns. Once a plot is completely built or torn down, it is claimed by a player. The first player to claim one of the following wins the game:

four plots in a row (orthogonally or diagonally)
four plots in a 2×2 square
four more plots than his opponent
a total of seven plots

boardgame.description:
This has been carried over from the original Clue (also known as Cluedo):
A person card, a weapon card, and a room card is removed from the deck and placed in an envelope. That envelope is placed in the center of the gameboard. The rest of the deck is shuffled and distributed to the players as evenly as possible. Each player now assumes the role of one of the suspects. The object of the game is to deduce which are the missing cards. In turn, the players will roll the dice and move their pawns to various rooms. Once in a room, the player may float a rumor as to which are the missing cards. If the person to the rumormonger’s immediate left can disprove the rumor by showing one of the cards mentioned, then the player must secretly reveal the card. Play continues until one person can identify the missing cards correctly, that person is the winner.

The version’s additions:
Each person has been given a unique power which may be used only once per game. There is an Intrigue deck which may or may not grant a player an extra action. Those Intrigue cards which do not grant an extra action are called Clock Cards. The player who draws the eighth Clock card is eliminated from play. Any player who draws a Clock Card thereafter is also eliminated. The “one” on one of the dice has been replaced by “?”. Any player who rolls “?” must draw an Intrigue card.

boardgame.name: Po Stopach Izenyru Hanzelky a Zykmunda z Prahy do Kapskeho mesta Osmickou Tatrou
boardgame.description:
Name of the game is really that long, it means translated:
"Following the paths of the engineers Hanzelka and Zykmund from Prague to Capetown with the 8-cylinder Tatra".

The engineers were employees of the Tatra Motor Works in Czecho then, and in times when car driving was still an adventure, especially in Africa, they made this journey to demonstrate the durability of their famous streamline car, the Tatra 87.

The journey lasted from 1947 to 1949, and was full of incidents.

Even some books about it were published, and this game followed.

The game is extremely scarce, and what makes it special is that the wooden game pawns are shaped like the abovementioned streamline car.

The rest is pure nostalgia, roll-and-move and some card-drafting.

Box and gameboard are extremely large: Box measures 20 x 15 inches, the board is 4 times as large !!!

boardgame.name: Hekumanhuippu
boardgame.description:
Hekumanhuippu (engl. Climax) is an erotic game for two lovers.

Players roll a die and move on a board with separate tracks for both towards the end, the climax. The tracks consist of four kind of points: Truth, Dare, Strip and Volcano. When a player enters a point (s)he must draw a corresponding action card from a pile, read it aloud and perform the given action. Some actions are quite innocuous, some bolder (especially in the endgame).

On both tracks there are a few points where players have to take a longer reroute, throw a die again or stop (ie. perform no action). If a player throws a six, (s)he must take six steps backwards making the game last even longer.

The player to reach the end (climax) first is the winner. (S)he may choose the prize or players can decide it together beforehand.

Contents:
-Game board
-47 Truth cards
-45 Dare cards
-12 Strip cards
-19 Volcano cards
-Two pawns
-A die
-Rules printed at the bottom of the box

Formosa Rail simulates ten years of railroad construction in Taiwan, bringing rapid ground transportation from north to south. Each player acts as one of the architects collecting five sources then constructs in four possible sites. Construction includes demolishing, tunnel and bridge building and track and station building. Player receives victory points for every construction and bonus victory point for most construction within a site. At the end of the game, player with the highest victory point wins.
